title: Dev2Prod - Synchronize your development and production tenants
content:
The Dev2Prod functionality supports configuration and data synchronization between any two tenants. The source and target tenants can belong to two suite systems or the same one, and can have the same tenant type (for example, development) or different types (for example, development and production). 

The process is quite simple. You only need to export configuration data from the source tenant to a package file (in .pkb format), and then import it into the target tenant. The feature also allows you to run a simulation import before the real import. Note that it may happen that your browser downloads an exported package without .pkb extension, and you need to append the extension to the package file name manually in this case. 

    Synchronizable resources

    Dev2Prod supports the synchronization of two types of resources between tenants: configurations and data. 

    Configurations

    Dev2Prod supports the synchronization of the following configurations:

    • User-defined fields (metadata), not including user options
    • Form layouts
    • Workflows
    • List enumerations, not including user options
    • Notification templates
    • Roles
    • Custom actions
    • Localization resource bundles (related to notification templates, user-defined fields, list enumerations, and more)
    • Service Level Target (SLT) settings
    • Menus
    • Access control
    • Inbox

    Take Native SACM into consideration

    When you have enabled Native SACM for one or both of the source and target tenants, refer to the following table for supported scenarios of using Dev2Prod.

    Source tenant Target tenant Supported scenario? Things to note
    Native SACM disabled Native SACM disabled Supported  No additional actions are needed.
    Native SACM enabled Native SACM enabled Supported  No additional actions are needed.
    Native SACM enabled Native SACM disabled Supported This can be an intentional step. Customers may clone the SACM studio data from the source (development) tenant to the target (production) tenant, monitor the system for a period of time, and then enable Native SACM in the target tenant later. 

    In this scenario, please be aware of the business rules that are intended for Native SACM scenes, such business rules may not work as expected before you eventually enable Native SACM in the target tenant. Therefore, if you are considering this approach, we recommend that you use a property called tenant_settings.ENABLE_CMSX to set a condition for business rules in the source tenant, thus making sure they are run only when Native SACM is enabled. 

    Note: When used in a business rule condition, the tenant_settings.ENABLE_CMSX property can have a value of true (Native SACM is enabled in tenant application settings) or false (Native SACM is disabled in tenant application settings). For example, the following condition allows the business rule to be run only when Native SACM is enabled:

    If ${tenant_settings.ENABLE_CMSX == true}
    Native SACM disabled Native SACM enabled Not supported The system won't stop you from synchronizing data using Dev2Prod. However, in this scenario, we strongly advise you against it.

    The tenant context changes in this scenario, specifically, business rules defined in the source tenant may not be applicable to the target tenant. For example, you have a business rule that sets the value of a federated attribute in the source tenant, which may be read-only in the Native-SACM-enabled target tenant. Forcing Dev2Prod may cause unpredictable issues in this scenario.

    OO business rules

    Dev2Prod supports Operations Orchestration (OO) business rules. Before you run Dev2Prod to synchronize OO business rules, you need to do the following in your target tenant:

    1. Create an OPB agent with the same name as the one used for your source OO endpoint.
    2. Create an OO endpoint with this OPB agent and specify the same Endpoint name and Location values as the source OO endpoint. It requires the dev and prod to be connected to the same OO. 

    Then, after a Dev2Prod synchronization, the OO business rules will work correctly in the target tenant without the need for any manual reconfiguration.

    Integration Studio business rules

    Dev2Prod supports Integration Studio business rules. However, as Dev2Prod doesn't support the synchronization of Integration Studio-based integrations, you need to do the following before you run Dev2Prod to synchronize Integration Studio business rules:

    1. In the target tenant, create an integration endpoint for each integration with the same name as the one in the source tenant.
    2. Use the Export and Import feature in Integration Studio to synchronize integrations and scenarios between the source and target tenants.

    Then, after a Dev2Prod synchronization, the Integration Studio business rules will work correctly in the target tenant without the need for any manual reconfiguration.

    Data

    Dev2Prod supports the synchronization of data records for entities in modules as described in the following table.

    Module Entities Notes
    Service Portfolio/Catalog
    • Categories
    • Service Definitions
    • Offerings
    • Fulfillment Plans
    For more information, see Dev2Prod - Synchronize Service Catalog content.
    For DND aggregated offerings, see Dev2Prod - Synchronize aggregated offerings
    Incident Models Limitation: After the Dev2Prod synchronization, the phase of the models will be changed to "Draft".
    Change Models
    Release Models

    Full and granular synchronization

    Dev2Prod supports both full and granular synchronization. 

    Full synchronization

    The Package Manager exports all configurations across modules from the source tenant and imports them into the target tenant. 

     
    • A full synchronization includes only system configurations; it doesn't synchronize any data records.
    • The source and target tenants must be on the same version.

    Granular synchronization

    A granular synchronization is helpful for importing incremental configuration and data changes from development to production. During a granular synchronization, the Package Manager exports only selected configuration changes and data changes from the source tenant, and imports the changes into the target tenant. 

    A granular synchronization can include both system configurations and data records. The source and target tenants may or may not need to be on the same version, depending on the package content. See the following table, where N+X stands for a version later than version N. Also, note that "data" refers to data records only and doesn't include configurations. ​​​​​
    Package content Source version Target version
    Configurations of OOTB applications N N
    Configurations of custom applications N N+X

    Data

     When exporting the package, you haven't selected the Configurations checkbox for any record types.
    		 N N+X
    Configurations of OOTB applications + data N N
    Configurations of custom applications + data N N+X
    All of the above N N

    Best practices

    • For packages that contain configurations, we recommend that you run the Dev2Prod import in a planned maintenance window. This is because the system might be inaccessible or not functioning during the import. 

      Importing packages that contain only data records won't cause any downtime and can be done at anytime.

    • To run a Dev2Prod synchronization, you must have the Tenant Admin role. For more information about this role, see Default roles.
    • Before running an export or import, ensure that the changes on the development tenant have been thoroughly tested.
    • If you are working with both development and production tenants, develop customizations, and perform testing and verification on the development tenant only, and then export configuration and data changes from the development tenant and then import them to the production tenant. No development should be done directly on the production tenant.
    • Before synchronizing your tenants, it's recommended to run a simulation of the synchronization and review the results. If there is a problem importing any part of the data, an error message is displayed. Click the Details link in the error message. An error report opens detailing each of the problematic issues. The issues that arise are usually related to conflicts between the two tenants. If the whole import fails, click the Details link for more information. The import might fail due to connection issues, timeout, wrong import files, and more. If there are no problems with the imported data, you can proceed with the actual import.

    Dev2Prod limitations

    Dev2Prod synchronization has the following limitations:

    • You can't run more than one import job in parallel per tenant. You must wait until the current job is completed before you can run a new one. 

    • It's recommended to leave your browser open until the export/import procedure is complete and you have received the results of the procedure. If you closed your browser, contact Support for the results.

    • To ensure that you are importing the latest data from the development tenant to the production tenant, export the data just before importing it to the production tenant. Attempting to import an older version of exported data might result in import failure due to inconsistencies.

    • If the language in your user profile is set to Chinese, Japanese, Korean, Russian, Greek, or Arabic, when you navigate to Administration > Utilities > Packages > Packages to open a package and then click List of Objects > Save As PDF, localized characters aren't displayed in the PDF exported. To work around this limitation, you can use Save As HTML instead.

    • Dev2Prod doesn't support the following capabilities: Software Asset Management (SAM),  Design and Deploy (DND), Operations Orchestration (OO), and Cloud Cost Reporting.

    • Dev2Prod doesn't support the synchronization of Integration Studio-based integrations. Use the Integration Studio's Export and Import feature to synchronize integrations and scenarios between tenants.
      This limitation doesn't apply to Integration Studio business rules. Dev2Prod supports Integration Studio business rules. See the "Integration Studio business rules" section for more information. 

    • Dev2Prod do esn't support the syn chronization of On-Premises Bridge (OPB) related settings. You need to perform post-import tasks in the target tenant:

      After the first import, you need to reconfigure the OPB agent, endpoint, and credentials records.
      After each import, you need to reconfigure all business rules that reference the endpoints, including rules configured in Studio and in offerings. This is required for each import because the rules in the source tenant will overwrite those in the target tenant after each new import.

      This limitation doesn't apply to OO business rules. Dev2Prod supports OO business rules. See the "OO business rules" section for more information. 

    • Dev2Prod doesn't support record level access control settings in Studio.

    • Dev2Prod does not support the synchronization of customizations made to the Inbox tab. After importing, any customizations needs to be handled manually.

    Inconsistency handling

    If inconsistencies are found during a configuration synchronization, they are treated as described in the following table.

    Data Inconsistency in System behavior
    User-defined fields in records Enable sort Source overwrites target.
    Read only Source overwrites target.
    Hidden Source overwrites target.
    Logical type Causes import process to fail.
    Reference Causes import process to fail.
    Enable search Causes import process to fail.
    Enforce uniqueness Causes import process to fail.
    Required Causes import process to fail.
    Field exists in target but not source Target field is deleted.
    Lists Source and target contain the same type of list with the same name, but with different list items

    List items from both lists are merged into one list.

    For more information about types of list in Service Management, see Lists.
    Source and target contain different types of list with the same name

    Import process fails.

    For more information about types of list in Service Management, see Lists.
    List item order Causes import process to fail
    List item icon Source overwrites target.
    Workflow definitions All Source overwrites target.

    This may cause inconsistencies in data in case the new workflow is inconsistent with existing data. For example, if a new validation rule was added to enforce a field’s value to be set (mandatory field), all records whose value for that field is empty, might return an error when updated.
    Form layout definitions All Source overwrites target.
    Notification templates All Source is merged into target.
    Index configurations All Source overwrites target.
    Roles All Source overwrites target.
    Custom actions All

    Source is merged into target.
    Resource bundles All Source overwrites target.
    Menus Name Causes import process to fail.
    Title Causes import process to fail.
    Header Causes import process to fail.

    If inconsistencies are found during a data synchronization, they are treated as described in Reconciliation approach. 

    Set a maximum allowed package size for import

    The suite administrator can define a maximum allowed package (.pkb) file size for import (including import simulation) per tenant:

    1. Log in to Suite Administration as the suite administrator.
    2. Open a tenant.
    3. Click the Application settings tab, and set a value in the Max Dev2Prod package file size (MB) field. The default value is 50 MB.
    This setting doesn't take effect when you export a .pkb package. 

    How to run a full synchronization

    The Package Manager enables you to export configuration data from your development tenant and import the data onto your production tenant. These are resources that can't be updated directly on your production tenant (except for resource bundles).

    To synchronize the entire configuration data from development to production, perform the following steps.

    Export the entire configurations from the development tenant

    1. Log in to your development tenant.
    2. From the main menu, select Administration > Utilities > Packages > OPTIONS.
    3. Click PACKAGE. If your browser is configured to save files automatically to the default download directory, you aren't prompted to save the file. You can access the package bundle file (user-customization-<tenant_ID>-yyyy-mm-dd hh-mm.pkb) in the browser's default download directory. You can open the package file (.pkb) in a compression tool, such as WinZip to view its content. There is one data file and one descriptor file for each object. Each data file is in good JSON or XML format and human-readable.

    Import the entire configurations into the production tenant

    1. Log in to your production tenant.
    2. From the main menu, select Administration > Utilities > Packages > Options.
    3. Click SIMULATE, browse to the package bundle file created previously, and click Open. The simulation automatically starts. Wait for the simulation to complete without error.
    4. Click IMPORT, and browse to the package bundle (.pkb) file to import it. A window opens and displays the progress and statistics of the package import process (the process may take a long time). The system imports and integrates the data into the production tenant.
    5. If you have a tenant key chain created in the development tenant, restore the tenant key chain in the production tenant (Administration > Configuration > Application Settings > Tenant key chain).

    How to run a granular synchronization

    The Package Manager also enables you to synchronize either or both of the following changes from your development tenant to production:

    • Configurations of desired entities of one or more modules
    • Data of supported entities of one or more modules

    To run a granular synchronization, perform the following steps.

    Export desired changes from the development tenant

    1. Log in to your development tenant.
    2. From the main menu, select Administration > Utilities > Packages > PACKAGES.
    3. Click New, enter a title, and optionally give information in other fields.
    4. Click SAVE.
    5. Open the new package from the list.
    6. In the Tags field, enter information that can help identify the package. For example, you can enter version information for the package. The system will save the tag information in a package-bundle-info.json file in the package bundle file (.pkb) that you will export in a later step.
    7. In the Content section, click Add to select one or more modules from the list and then click OK. To remove an existing module from the list, click the down arrow icon for that module and then click Remove.
    8. Select a module to bring up a list of related entities for the module, and then select one or more entities from the list. For example, if you added a new field to the Full EntityModel form (Administration > Studio > Model), select the Change module, and then select Models from the Related entities list. If you want to view the details of an entity, click the down arrow icon for that entity and then select Go to studio. Note that when you click the down arrow icon, a Content pane is also displayed and a Configurations checkbox (a Data checkbox as well if applicable) is selected by default on that pane. If you clear this checkbox, the system won't export the corresponding entity. 
    9. Repeat the previous step for the remaining modules that you added.
    10. (Optional) If you also want to export Service Catalog data, see Dev2Prod - Synchronize Service Catalog content. 
    11. Click Save. The new package is displayed in the package list.
    12. Open the package record from the package list.
      Note: When you open a package record that contains custom modules or custom entities, if the corresponding custom applications or entities have been modified in the backend (Studio > Menu), you will see that the package's Content is automatically synchronized. For example, a module or entity's label is automatically updated, newly added entities are automatically added to the entity list (but not selected), and newly deleted entities are shown in strikethrough text.
    13. Click the List of Objects button to preview the content to be exported. Additionally, you can save the preview content as HTML or PDF simply by clicking a button.
    14. Click Export. If your browser is configured to save files automatically to the default download directory, you aren't prompted to save the file. You can access the package bundle file (Package-<package ID>-<tenant ID>-yyyy-mm-dd hh-mm.pkb) in the browser's default download directory. You can open the package file (.pkb) in a compression tool, such as WinZip to view its content. There's one data file and one descriptor file for each object. Each data file is in good JSON or XML format and human-readable.

    Import the desired changes into the production tenant

    1. Log in to your production tenant.
    2. From the main menu, select Administration > Utilities > Packages > Options.
    3. Click SIMULATE, browse to the package bundle file created before, and click Open. The simulation automatically starts. Wait for the simulation to complete without error.
    4. Click IMPORT, and browse to the package bundle (.pkb) file to import it. A window opens and displays the progress and statistics of the package import process (the process may take a long time). The system imports and integrates the package content into the production tenant.
    5. Verify the imported configuration and data changes in the target tenant.
    6. If you have a tenant key chain created in the development tenant, restore the tenant key chain in the production tenant (Administration > Configuration > Application Settings > Tenant key chain). 

    Use API calls to perform a synchronization

    Service Management provides a REST API that, together with the Case Exchange API, you can use to perform Dev2Prod synchronization. Reference information these APIs is available in the following topics:

    • Dev2Prod REST API
    • Case Exchange REST API

    Prerequisites

    You have already generated a full or granular export package on the source tenant, as described above.

    Workflow and examples

    The workflow is as follows:

    1. Run the https://{serverAddress}/rest/{tenant_id}/dev2prod/export/types/{id} POST method API to export the package to the File Repository Service (FRS). The expected response is the export ID.

      Example
      This example exports package "54321" on tenant 123456789.

      API:

      https://company.net/rest/123456789/dev2prod/export/types/54321

      Response body: 
      {
 "Id": "66fabdf1e4b06908b04d4051"
}
    2. Use the export ID returned in the previous step to run the https://{serverAddress}/rest/{tenant_id}/dev2prod/export/{id} GET method API and view the export details.

      Example
      This example queries export "66fabdf1e4b06908b04d4051" on tenant 123456789.

      API:

      https://company.net/rest/123456789/dev2prod/export/66fabdf1e4b06908b04d4051

      Response body: 
      	{
	    "id": "6797556be4b0c05084915394",
	    "PackageBundleName": "Package-54321-123456789-2025-01-27 09-44",
	    "Status": "COMPLETED",
	    "FileId": "c7e87b89-f214-4766-8032-bba6967e1c49",
	    "StartTime": 1737971051843,
	    "LastUpdateTime": 1737971053134,
	    "ItemCount": 352,
	    "Statistics": [
	        {
	            "PackageName": "metadata",
	            "ItemCount": 0
	        },
	        {
	            "PackageName": "workflow",
	            "ItemCount": 24
	        },
	        {
	            "PackageName": "formLayouts",
	            "ItemCount": 117
	        },
	        {
	            "PackageName": "customAction",
	            "ItemCount": 0
	        },
	        {
	            "PackageName": "indexConfiguration",
	            "ItemCount": 0
	        },
	        {
	            "PackageName": "featureInstances",
	            "ItemCount": 26
	        },
	        {
	            "PackageName": "uiComponentConfig",
	            "ItemCount": 0
	        },
	        {
	            "PackageName": "notificationTemplateDefinitions",
	            "ItemCount": 88
	        },
	        {
	            "PackageName": "notificationTemplateBodies",
	            "ItemCount": 97
	        },
	        {
	            "PackageName": "SLTTenantSetting",
	            "ItemCount": 0
	        },
	        {
	            "PackageName": "data",
	            "ItemCount": 0
	        },
	        {
	            "PackageName": "userOptionMetadata",
	            "ItemCount": 0
	        },
	        {
	            "PackageName": "rulesInEntity",
	            "ItemCount": 0
	        },
	        {
	            "PackageName": "many2manyRelations",
	            "ItemCount": 0
	        },
	        {
	            "PackageName": "attachments",
	            "ItemCount": 0
	        },
	        {
	            "PackageName": "customAppSltSettings",
	            "ItemCount": 0
	        },
	        {
	            "PackageName": "resourceBundles",
	            "ItemCount": 0
	        }
	    ],
	    "OperationType": "Export"
	}
    3. Run the https://{serverAddress}/rest/{tenant_id}/ces/attachment/{attachment_id} GET method API to download the exported package to the source tenant. Use the FileID value from the previous response as the attachment ID. The expected response is ?
       

      Example
      This example downloads package "c7e87b89-f214-4766-8032-bba6967e1c49" on tenant 123456789.

      API:

      https://company.net/rest/123456789/dev2prod/ces/attachment/c7e87b89-f214-4766-8032-bba6967e1c49
    4. Run the https://{serverAddress}/rest/{tenant_id}/ces/attachment POST method API to upload the package to FRS.
       

      Example
      This example uploads package "??" on tenant 123456789.

      API:

      https://company.net/rest/123456789/ces/attachment

      Request body: 
      {
 ??
}

      Response body: 
      {
 "Id": "66fabdf1e4b06908b04d4051"
}
    5. Run the https://{serverAddress}/rest/{tenant_id}/dev2prod/import?dryRun=true POST method API to simulate importing the package to the target tenant.
       

      Example
      This example simulates importing package "c7e87b89-f214-4766-8032-bba6967e1c49" on tenant 123456789.

      API:

      https://company.net/rest/123456789/dev2prod/import?dryRun=true

      Request body: 
      {
  "FileId": "c7e87b89-f214-4766-8032-bba6967e1c49"
}

      Response body: 
      {
 "Id": "66fabdf1e4b06908b04d4051"
}
    6. Run the https://{serverAddress}/rest/{tenant_id}/dev2prod/import/{id} GET method API to check the import status. If there are no errors, the import dry-run was successful, and you can import the package.
       

      Example
      This example checks the status of import "66fabdf1e4b06908b04d4051" on tenant 123456789.

      API:

      https://company.net/rest/123456789/dev2prod/import/66fabdf1e4b06908b04d4051

      Response body: 
      {
    "TimeToLive": 9946986,
    "StudioLocked": false,
    "SystemLocked": false,
    "id": "66fabdf1e4b06908b04d4051",
    "FileId": "c7e87b89-f214-4766-8032-bba6967e1c49",
    "Status": "COMPLETED",
    "DryRun": true,
    "PackageManagerId": "67975a8be4b0c050849153b2",
    "StartTime": 1737972352849,
    "LastUpdateTime": 1737972406603,
    "ProcessingServerName": "company-server",
    "Results": [
        {
            "PackageName": "metadata",
            "Statistics": {
                "Modified": 300,
                "Removed": 0,
                "Failed": 0,
                "Skipped": 0
            },
            "Errors": [],
            "Warnings": []
        },
        {
            "PackageName": "SLTTenantSetting",
            "Statistics": {
                "Modified": 0,
                "Removed": 0,
                "Failed": 0,
                "Skipped": 0
            },
            "Errors": [],
            "Warnings": []
        },
        {
            "PackageName": "indexConfiguration",
            "Statistics": {
                "Modified": 26,
                "Removed": 0,
                "Failed": 0,
                "Skipped": 0
            },
            "Errors": [],
            "Warnings": []
        }
    ],
    "Totals": {
        "Added": 0,
        "Modified": 326,
        "Removed": 0,
        "Failed": 0,
        "Skipped": 0
    },
    "OperationType": "Import"
}
    7. Run the https://{serverAddress}/rest/{tenant_id}/dev2prod/import POST method API to import the package to the source tenant.
       

      Example
      This example imports package "c7e87b89-f214-4766-8032-bba6967e1c49" on tenant 123456789.

      API:

      https://company.net/rest/123456789/dev2prod/import

      Request body: 
      {
  "FileId": "c7e87b89-f214-4766-8032-bba6967e1c49"
}
      Response body: 
      {
 "Id": "66fabdf1e4b06908b04d4051"
}
